Award.AbstractNarration:
This project focuses on slab mass transport into the lower mantle. It will, 1), expand the range of constraints on the degree of slab stagnation, e.g. by detailed analysis of transition zone thickness as well as hypothesis-driven reinversion of seismological data; 2), construct, by means of further software development, regional dynamic models and simplified global parameterizations for stagnation systematics in a thermo-chemical, multi-phase transition mantle system; and, 3), benchmark these computational convection models for vertical and horizontal transport. A graduate student from an under-represented group will be trained in interdisciplinary research. All project software will be developed openly and shared freely online. The tomographic inversion and modeling tools will be implemented into the Solid Earth Teaching and Research Environment software framework, allowing data-driven hypothesis testing for entirely different geodynamic questions and facilitating the training of Earth science students in interdisciplinary research.

Better estimates of the slab flux, over time and with error bars, will help to constrain geochemical mixing and thermal Earth evolution models. The study will contribute to the use of slabs for absolute plate-tectonic reference frames, and slab dynamics has other, broad implications such as on net rotations of the lithosphere with respect to the lower mantle, interactions with the super-continental cycle, and sealevel variations.

ProgramReference.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project allowed for the development of numerical models of plate tectonics. We studied the subduction of lithospheric plates and how such slabs deform themselves, affect the plates at the surface, and "talk" to each other. We showed that the relationship between the angle of subduction, as inferred from earthquakes, and the thickness of the overriding plate means that slabs weaken by plastic rather than viscous deformation. This is circumstantial but important evidence for how laboratory derived deformation laws apply over tectonic timescales. These findings are also consistent with our recent analysis of GPS recorded deformation after the 2011 Tohoku M9 earthquake, where we find reduction in plate strength in the depth regions where such plastic behavior would be expected. 

By intergrating modeling with geological and geophysical observations, we were also able to show how two interacting slabs accelerate plates, and modify the relative motion of the trenches in a deep mantle reference frame. Such systems of slab-slab interactions exist at present surrounding the Philippine Sea plate, where we explain the history of trench motion and slab dips based on slab interactions. For plate reconstructions, we also suggest that slab-slab interactions can be invoked to explain the anomalously fast motion of the greater India plate ~50 myrs ago.

In general, our models indicate that it is important to account for the feedbacks between large-scale plate motions and crustal as well as overriding plate structure. This complicates the subduction process, but also highlights ways of better understanding of plate coupling, with possible implications for the propensity of subduction thrust systems to generate mega earthquakes.

Besides supporting this fundamental research that may feed into future models of the subduction zone earthquake cycle, NSF funding also supported the career development of a graduate student who is now continuing his research as a post-doc at MIT, and the formation of new collaborations, including with colleagues in Europe.
